text:
We built our employee
app on Amazon Bedrock,
and it's been hugely successful
for the airline and its growth.
So we could see some obvious cost savings
in that as well.

Going to be able to do a
lot more distance learning,

and it's just a better
product to be delivered.

We're able to generate
experiences and itineraries
at 80% less the cost of manually curated.

We processed 300,000
summaries in an automated way
in about six weeks.

And so that's something
that we could not do before
that we can do now.

We would review about
20% of those manually
through these legal editing process.

We were able to upload
and train the model,

and we established that
for the 4,000 hotels,
it would take 10 hours to train the model

and deliver the output we needed
for the measly cost of $70.
So a fantastic output

delivering exceptional
content and very quickly.
We can now generate automated content
that previously took eight hours,
we can deliver that in under 10 seconds.

All these things have been
very flexible with Bedrock,

and it is quicker time to
market from what I can see.
We are able to test all these things,
see the comparison with different model,
different performance criteria,
so that's what Bedrock brings in.

We use Amazon Bedrock
to read a legacy PNR,
or passenger reservation.
The fact that we could take something
that was a 50-year-old technology

and train Amazon Bedrock to
read what was built 50 years ago

and bring it into modern
times was amazing.
Something that would take three hours

for someone to research came
back in a matter of seconds.
It has changed my team's outlook

on how we're approaching
the modernization.
We're no longer thinking about,
how do we replicate what we have?
We're thinking about how do we innovate,
how do we build better for our customers
and the products that we support?
